This is probably one of the best examples of 'mixed bags' that I can think of. Resident Evil 6 is both great and horrible in so many ways I won't be able to go over them all but for that reason alone I feel it's a game for anyone who considers themselves a 'gamer' should play at least once to see what I mean.    RE6 is an action title with the occasional horror aesthetic thrown in to tie itself in whith its lineage. While best played with a friend it's very much playable solo. Players will take control one of 3 pairs of characters (or possibly an additional duo or a single character for the fourth campaign) as they experience the story of the game from three different perspectives and this is where the idea of the mixed bag begins. Instead of a single cohearent script, its divided amoungst three different stories that constantly leaves the player confused and in a stupor. Even with all the campaigns completed I had to read some of the in-game lore from the easily missed extras menu once I shot enough blue emblems in the game. While the Resident Evil series isn't known for its story, previous entries were at least easy to understand, not the case with this title, often throwing characters at the player that even veterans have no idea as to who they are.   Controling the characters is another issue for this game. In many games designed with a controller in mind, often times a button is used as a modifier for every other button. In previous games, what would be holding down the left trigger would then make the character aim at which point the right will fire. While that is a simple method, RE6 has layers of these that are poorly explained if at all. New players should take their time figuring out the controls as even into my second campaign I was still learning what certain combinations of buttons and motions did. However once learned, the complex control scheme actually makes for excellent stylish feats but not everyone will get used to them.   Probably one of the best things about the title is how it can incorporate multiplayer into the campaign. With certain options selected, a player can allow others online to join the game as a co op partner, random players to take control of basic enemies for a little extra challange, and even run into other players who are in other campaigns in overlapping story sections where up to four players can take on a segment of their campaigns together. The only problem with this is that due to the small playerbase many of these things wont happen without coordination with other players such as through Steam groups.   While there is definitly more to say I feel that these are some of the biggest issues. I do enjoy the game despite all its faults, however I will say that it may be my least favorite of the RE series that I have experienced. Many others damn this game as complete garbage, and while not all of their complaints are invalid or wrong, it does have entertainment value and some excellent points. If you are looking for a coop third-person action title, there are not many on the market but you should not settle for this unless you are already played through better titles. Give it a look but be aware it is flawed.

So the short and skinny of Resident Evil 6   There are 4 campaigns to play through that intertwine with each other that can lead to a lot of similar fights and locations being revisited. This can makes the game campaigns feel slightly lazy in comparison to previous games. However, other than the final campaign mission that was offered as dlc, each campaign is approximately 4 hours long. You couple the repetitiveness of the main campaign with some very Bollywood action sequences and it really is a toss-up whether or not you will enjoy it. Personally, I had no problem with it because if you can accept monsters, mutants, and zombies then you might as well suspend disbelief on the rest as well.   Where the game really REALLY shines is the mobility of play style and improved combat system. There is sliding, rolling, jumping onto your back, running (like really running, not just the light jog from previous games), countering attacks, and a bit more.    Oh and it has  LOCAL COOP , the fact is, if you have one friend, just one friend that will visit you to play games Resident Evil 6 is fantastic. Sure, the way the split screen works is a bit funky and very poorly implemented but I personally have zero problems with it. Therefore, if you have a single friend to play games with and an extra controller I promise you your game play will generally be a lot of fun. However, if you play Resident Evil 6 alone, the game will be a bit of a slog at times.  Despite some obvious negatives you do get your money's worth when purchasing this game.

Resident Evil 6 (RE6) is the third Resident Evil game I’ve played (only played 4, 5, and 6 since I don’t have a Playstation). The game has a relatively low metacritic rating (69 last I checked) but I found it to be exactly what I expected after playing RE5 a year earlier. If you’ve only seen the Resident Evil movies then you may not be aware that the games have a completely different storyline and I think they’ve been retconned a few times as well. You would probably recognize a bunch of the characters though since almost every Resident Evil character I know appears in RE6.  The game is a third person “over the shoulder” game played in coop with another person. Just like Resident Evil 5, if you don’t have a friend playing with you, the computer controls the other guy. There are 4 campaigns for you to play and in each of them you can play one of the 2 characters. The campaigns all intersect multiple times so you might be playing the Leon campaign and run in to Chris Redfield. Then when you’re playing the Chris campaign you run into Leon and play as the other side of the encounter. It’s a great way to see the plot from various viewpoints and you’ll understand why characters are acting in a certain way. After you’ve completed the game you can go back and play as the second character in each campaign as well. There’s over 50 hours of gameplay to be had in single player alone. Each campaign is divided into chapters and each chapter into sections, for example Leon Campaign Chapter 1-1, 1-2, 1-3, etc. The game saves at checkpoints during each section, so if you’re knocked out and your partner doesn’t revive you in time, you restart at the checkpoint. Your inventory is saved between sections and you can replay previous sections freely. There is no more “inventory screen,” now it’s just a quick menu where you hold a button to display and scroll through your items. There is no level up system, but you can gather “exp” points to unlock perks such as improved damage or better aim stability. Then you can pick which 3 perks you want equipped between missions. So you can replay levels over and over for more exp or replay some of the bosses a few times for fun.  I believe the complaint that a lot of Resident Evil purists had was that beginning with RE5, the games aren’t really “survival horror” anymore. Now the focus is on action and shooting. I remember in RE4 that conserving ammunition was a big challenge so you use melee attacks as much as possible. The melee system has been enhanced a great deal since then and ammunition has become a lot more plentiful (you can also replay levels to grab ammo and then just save + quit). You’ll definitely do a lot of shooting, but you should definitely master the hand to hand (or knife fighting depending on which character you’re playing).   Storywise, the game picks up a few years after Resident Evil 5. The world is continuing to circle the drain as various warlords around the world use biological weapons to create zombies and other super powered monsters. Each campaign has its own antagonist though they cross over a lot, as mentioned earlier. If you haven’t played the previous games you might not understand a few “peculiarities” of the playable characters. I certainly didn’t know who some of the people were and the ways that their backstories drive the game’s plot. It is mostly understandable though if you play the whole game through. Just accept that everyone knows each other from previous games.  Pros: +Excellent built in co-op play for the campaign, and for different game modes like Mercenaries. Steam sells the “complete pack” that includes everything, kind of like a Game of the Year edition. +Very long game (at least 35 hours even if you rush), you’ll get your money’s worth. +A lot of replay value (you can unlock “perks” by grinding for exp). +You can play as a monster! Join someone’s game and ♥♥♥♥ them up. A few people tried dropping into my brother and my games, but since we were on levels with only normal zombie enemies (so they spawned as normal zombies), we blew them away easily lol.  Cons: -Multi player is kind of dead now. Hard to find a game to join unless it’s a friend inviting you or vice versa. -According to Resident Evil “purists” the game is more action than “survival horror.” If you’re new to Resident Evil games and just looking for a co-op shooter, this won’t bother you. -There are a few times when you need to run through an area in a short amount of time (like escaping a giant enemy) and the camera keeps subtly shifting so you slightly change running directions and hit a wall or something, then you die. This is VERY annoying but only happens in a few areas. Most of the time you can play leisurely.  Overall I would definitely recommend Resident Evil 6 if you like action games and / or zombie bashing games. The visuals are disturbing and the monsters are grotesque, as expected in a Resident Evil game. The game is 100% better if you have a friend to join your game for coop play. And once you’re done with the campaigns you can spend a lot of time on the various game modes that are included, most especially the Mercenaries mode, which returns from Resident Evil 5. It’s kind of like a survival mode where you try to live to the end of the timer killing as many enemies as you can. The enemy types keep changing until you’re fighting mini bosses.

Terrible game. There's a lot of content, but it's stretched thin. Has multiple campaigns with quite a bit of recycled content in each one. Makes you watch the same long cutscenes repeatedly. Controls are awful and inventory management is unintuitive and clunky. The melee combat is frustrating; moves are supposed to be contextual so when you go to strike an enemy on the ground you should stomp on them, but sometimes your character will decide to swing the air above them instead. I was in a coop game where my partner had a zombie pin him on the ground, so I turned around and repeatedly roundhouse kicked the air above the zombie while it ate his face off. The button to run is the same button to climb ladders and jump up or down ledges so you will frequently do one thing when you meant to do another. It has bad checkpointing so you'll replay tedious sections repeatedly. It's full of unecessary and annoying quicktime events that cause instant game overs, far more than any other Resident Evil game. It also has a major bug in Jake's campaign that halts progression in coop that requires a workaround to continue progression.   The worst part of the game is it frequently takes away control to make you look at something the game wants to tell you is important, unfortunately the enemies don't stop when this happens so the game is full of cheap deaths where you will be killed by an enemy that approached you and jumped on you during a cutscene. See a zombie approaching you? No problem, I'll just take out my shotgun... no the game wants me to look at some random door that I would've found myself... and I'm on the ground with the zombie on top of me and I'm dead.   The game is full of heavily scripted sequences. The game wants you to conserve ammo, but it is also full of scripted encounters with bosses with high health pools, and shooting them will either damage them or not depending on whether or not you're in a scripted sequence or not. It is beyond frustrating to use half your ammo on a boss only to realise that you can't actually damage him yet because the game hadn't decided you're at the scripted point in which you can. Once you have played these encounters out a few times you will begin to wonder every time you reach a boss whether you should shoot him or not or wait for a truck to run him over (often the correct decision). It doesn't just affect bosses but normal enemies. During quicktime events your partner will often not be able to do anything to help you. In my coop game a zombie grabbed my partner and slowly killed him over the course of about half a minute. During that time I unloaded half my shotgun ammo into him, a zombie type we had encountered before and typically took two rounds to take down. But because the game decided the only important thing was whether he passed the quicktime event, that zombie was invincible. You will also run into zombies lying on the ground numerous times that you know are obvious threats. You can shoot them but your bullets will have no impact. Even though you know they're a threat, you have to walk past them where they will stand up and are only then able to be damaged.   The coop is poor compared to Resident Evil 5 or other coop games. There is no resource sharing so if your partner runs out of ammo and you have a ton, that person is just going to have to go on a punching spree until they find some more. You can't give first aid kits or medical supplies to your partner either, although you can use them on them. This is such a basic feature and it was important in Resident Evil 5, so its omission here is glaring.   It doesn't play like a survival horror game; I don't have any problem with that in itself but the game is trying to be an action game instead. When you compare it to other action games it doesn't hold up well at all. If you are considering buying this game, get Gears or War, Bulletstorm, Spec Ops: The Line, or one of the newer Tomb Raider games. Or Resident Evil 4. They're all significantly better than this game and tread the same ground.

Biohazard 6 is a difficult game to class. On the one hand, it does so many things right, and on the other, some things horribly wrong.  The story is split into 4 campaigns, each with their own gameplay and style; Leon S. Kennedy and Helena Harper team up to take on a traditional zombie outbreak, Chris Redfield and Piers Nevans have an all-out war on terror, Jake Muller and Sherry Burkin battle near-invincible bosses, and Ada Wong solves both gameplay and plot puzzles. Leon and Helena's campaign is the best, with a great atmosphere and fun gameplay involving traditional zombies, with Ada's campaign 2nd for it's plot and puzzle elements. Jake and Sherry have the most unique gameplay, due to Jake's Melee ability complimenting Sherry's ranged ability, with QTEs holding it back from being the better. Chris and Piers share the worst of the four, with their campaign being about as cliche and boring as your average military bromance story. They do crossover, both in terms of style, gameplay and story, and they do all contribute to an overarching story, which is convoluted but interesting enough that it held my attention from beginning to end.  Gameplay is were the game really shines and shows it's unique identity. Movement and combat is a smooth, fast and fluid ride for the most part, broken up by the bane of my existence: Quick Time Events. With gameplay as good as it is, I'm simply lost to find any reason why they thought filling their game with these boring, tiresome interactive cinematics. The excellent combat mechanics, which include dodges, rolls, cover and some character specific moves, are more than enough to carry the game. The other stuff on offer, however, is not. Some driving sequences from Chris and Jake's campaigns are more painful than fun, Ada's helicoper level is mostly boring point and click, and some other odd choices make some sections of the campaign more trouble than it's worth. Multiplayer also handles an odd mix; while the basic combat mechanics are great in modes such as Mercenaries, Mercenaries No Hope, Versus and the other modes that handle normal characters play well, others, such as Agent Hunt, which puts you in the role of a zombie in the campaign, controls awful and feels sluggish. Also, don't bother with the gamepad. It works, but barely, and the keyboard has hotkeys which will make your gameplay experience so much better.  The music and audio is all around high quality, with excellent voice acting, great music and fantastic audio cues enhance the gameplay and the story to awesome hieghts. It played exceptionally well on my 5.1 Surround Sound system and was a thrill to blast the sound to it's maximum levels.  Graphics are all around great. The HUD is small and keeps out of the way for the most part, but the itmes menu could have been handled better. The textures are decent aside from some low-res environmental textures, and the lighting is beautiful. Animations, Capcoms strongest point, I think, is fantastic, though some feel like they're too exagerated and overlong. The art design holds up well and is overall a great-looking game.  Story - 7/10 Gameplay - 6/10 Audio - 9/10 Graphics - 8/10 Controls - 8/10  Total - 38/50  The game ran in max graphics, minus the Anti-Aliasing, at 60fps, with the following specs:  Windows 7 64bit Intel i5 750 2.6GHz Nvidia 250GT 1GB 4 GB RAM 1920x1200 Monitor

So, what can I say about this game? It's a modern Resident Evil title. It took a few good things from Revelations 1, one nice thing from the old titles and a lot of bad stuff from a lot of other Resi titles. But I'm getting ahead of myself. If you want to skip the lengthy part of my review, you can find the pros and cons list below.  First things first: the story. The story is a bit bigger this time around. For one thing, it's because of the fact that it features five campaigns. On the other hand it's because this time the story centers around the fate of the world - AGAIN! Well. But it doesn't feel as insignificant as Revelations 1 since you'll be fighting against a lot of ♥♥♥♥ in the USA, China, Edonia and other places. An organization by the name of Neo Umbrella has risen and is terrorizing the world with... well... bioterrorism. Like in all the other games. But the game looks better than its predessecors. So that's a plus. Anyway. The main character cast centers around Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield, Sherry Birkin, Ada Wong along with their respective sidekicks. Also there's Albert Wesker's son but I won't spoiler anything. These people are trying to save the day by defeating Neo Umbrella. That's more or less the gist of it.  Fans of the old games will be pleased to hear that you'll be fighting classic zombies from time to time. When you first start the game with Leon you'll be watching limping half-corpses around a city in the USA and when you're in China you'll be seeing them there, too. On enemy variety the devs were pretty creative again. But nothing too new tbh. You got the classic zombies, you got the J'avo. The J'avo are somewhat like the Majini and Ganados, only more extreme and instead of a parasite there's a virus responsible for their mutations. The J'avo have some surprises up their sleeve when it comes to mutations so that's not all too bad. These are the main enemy types. But the bosses are where it's really at. Remember El Gignte? You'll be fighting a couple of those in this game (not like the farce of an El Gigante in RE 5). Then there's a bunch of hulking creatures of plates and muscle with are ♥♥♥♥ing annyoing to defeat because they're bullet sponges. And some other boss battles with a giant, invisible snake, crazy people who thought injecting a dose of the virus into themselves was a good idea (didn't see THAT one coming *chuckles*) and some other ♥♥♥♥ I don't wanna spoiler.  But wherever there's an enemy, there oughtta be a weapon to defeat it, right? Yes! Weapons wise there's a lot. In every campaign you'll be getting different weapons and every character you play as has a different set of starting weapons to begin with. Over the course of each campaign you'll acquire new weapons and you will find a lot of uses for each of them. And yes, there's an elephant killer magnum gun again. But as always, it's ♥♥♥♥ing hard to find any ammo for this thing so hear my advice and use it in boss battles or if absolutely nessecary. Like when you'll be fighting against those chainsaw ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s (that are EVEN harder to kill this time around). Aside from that there's a bunch of stationary weapons and some are one time use only.  But the best part about this is: in theory you don't even need weapons most of the time because they finally improved the melee combat. meaning that you can now punch and kick your way through hordes of enemies. Given that they don't shoot you down. Warning: not recommended on harder difficulties because it's generally a dumb idea to only do melee fighting in any Resi game. Well, usually if you have to do that you're bsaically screwed and might as well start over. In this one you can deal considerable damage to your enemies with melee combat. Which is a plus. Also the animation set for melee combat is quite nice to look at.  On the technical side of things the game runs fine on highest setting, no FPS drops, no crashes. Only one time it didn't recognize my save file but that problem was quickly sorted out so fear not, you won't have any technical issues with this one. At least I didn't have any. Game mechanics wise there's a lot of stuff I didn't like and some stuff I was really fond of. As I mentioned earlier, there's half-decent melee combat now, which is a plus. Then you may move while aiming and shooting. First Resi game that brought that one to us was Revelations 1, I believe. Which is a great plus. They finally noticed just how useful this feature is. Knife fighting is no more, you instead screw 'em with your guns in melee combat. Also a good idea. What else? Well, you can walk, run, shoot, hit, die, survive, climb, jump down (a lot of these actions may require you to stand at specific positions however. Resi style) and, when playing with Ada, use your grappling hook. Oh and there's skills now. Like, you collect skill points and after each chapter or so you can buy and upgrade skills with them. The idea's nice but ultimately useless as I didn't use them all that often. Only scenario where I could imagine them being useful would be on the really high difficulties that aren't even fun anymore. Also the partner mechanic is back but it isn't annyoing anymore. Now enemies target your partner too (not like RER) and you almost never have to worry about them dying (unlike RE5). Aside from that it's standard 3rd Person Shooter. Oh, but wait! They are back. More gloriously than ever before. They Q to the T to the E. QTE sections en masse with this game. I mean, I can understand it having a few QTEs in the game. But in Resi 6 they are pretty much used excessively. Not as bad as most of the reception is putting it but it's not like they had any QTEs left after this one. There are a lot of scenes where you just have to smash a few buttons to come forward and avoid death. At least some of the QTEs are creative in the sense that they require you to click at a specific time. But yeah, they're still QTEs.  What else? I got a few gripes with this game QTE wise, yeah. But the worst part is that the credits are unskippable. That wouldn't be so bad if: The credits weren't so long because a trillion people worked on this game and you wouldn't have to watch them five times. Why five times? Well, there are five campaigns and after completing each campaign you are required to watch those unskippable, long-♥♥♥ credits.   And the final piece of information will be the subtle humour in the game which is most prevalent in Jake's campaign because Jake is just the badass guy who doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ about most of it and just does his thing along with his audible drek. It's funny, really. Mostly anyway.  So, to wrap this up, pros and cons!  Pros: + Improved graphics + The story isn't too bad (and feels WAY more significant than RER's) + Most of the mechanics in the game are improved + Different animation sets for a lot of enemies (not unlike some OTHER games. Yeah RE5, I'm lookin' at you) + Oldschool zombie slashing action in the first few hours of the game bringing back good memories + Awesome death scenes. Seriously, to die in this game can look pretty cool. There's even an achievement for that + Fairly good melee combat and gunplay + Ludicrous bosses that are even more crazy than before (I like that stuff) + Good enemy variety + NO QTEs IN CUTSCENES + Replayability because you can choose between two characters playing a campaign and each of them is a different approach + And more  Cons! - A thousand QTEs - Unskippable credits - Linear gameplay and story (as always) - Horror? Lol, no - Boring 'puzzles' - You'll die frequently because of some QTEs - I got nothing more honestly  Would I recommend this game? Yeah, it's good for what it does. At 20 bucks? Maybe think about it. If you're a hardcore Resi fan then yes, if you just like 3rd person shooters wait for a sale.

This is from the perspective of someone who has played the Xbox version first, and the PC version second. The Good of this port is the same for the Xbox version, and I will review it as an action game, not a horror game. It is clearly not meant to be scary, but to be fun and make you feel awesome for breaking through all that it can throw at you. If you are unable to accept that Resident Evil is no longer meant to frighten you, you will likely hate this game for straying so far from its roots and reputation for scares. If you are able to look past the reputation of Resident Evil, read on.   The Good: (what to consider when purchasing)  Resident Evil has never had such tight, fluid controls. The new movement and dodge mechanics make you feel like a badass, tucking and sliding out of the way in real time, through your own skill rather than a contextual quick time event as it used to be. Reversal attacks add a layer of cool that no other entry in the series before it has had. You're now able to turn the flow of combat from hectic run-and-gunning into a scene straight out of a kung-fu B movie, rewarding you for your quick reflexes and giving you much needed breathing room when the enemies swarm you. What could be more awesome than grabbing a leaping zombie out of the air and stomping on it before whipping around, kicking another so hard it spins backwards on its heels, then slamming it into the ground with a DDT from behind? Probably while doing it as classic Resident Evil characters, which this game thoughtfully provides.  The gameplay varies between campaigns, as you would expect. Leon's focuses more on melee combat than the rest due to scarce ammunition and the zombies' resistance to bullet damage. Expect to be punished harshly for not getting your reversal timing down, as zombies behave unpredictably; Leaping at random, tripping over their own feet, lunging from the floor to pull you down with them, etc. Chris' campaign is full on testosterone infused action, hardly a dull moment to be found and plenty of fun enemy types to encounter and learn the weaknesses of. J'avo are much more predictable than the zombies, but are able to use ranged weaponry, making combat much more reliant on cover. Ada's campaign is a little more like the Resident Evil we recognize, with more puzzles and being rewarded for avoiding enemy contact, though obviously that's not possible most of the time as this is still an action game. Jake's campaign is a mix of the three, combining the over-the-top melee combat of Leon's campaign, the cover based shooting of Chris' and the enemy avoidance of Ada's. It works well, though can be a bit schitzophrenic as you would be required to change playstyle often.  The game has a wealth of content because of these four campaigns, and if playtime is something you consider when buying a game, you'd get your money's worth here for the sheer amount of it all. It's not Skyrim levels of vast, but for the type of game it was aiming to be, it certainly could have been a lot less. *cough-cough-OperationRaccoonCity-cough*   The Bad: (nitpicks and gripes)  While all that's well and good, there are moments where the camera will suddenly yank away from your perspective and focus on something in the background, but still have combat continue around you. This leaves you helpless as enemies are allowed to swarm in closer, or your precious ammo is wasted as you start shooting at a door that just opened because the game insisted on pulling the camera away to show it to you. Though the gameplay is varied between the campaigns, all of them begin to lose steam half way through. Leon's campaign recycles boss fights to the Nth degree, so much so that you may get frustrated as you have to repeat the same fights over and over with little to no variation between them. Past chapter 3, Chris' campaign just throws more and more enemies at you in the despirate attempt to heighten tension more than it had the previous chapters, though because there's nothing really different from them it just feels like an annoying slog. There is a moment where you take control of a jump jet, but it never happens again and it's over in about five minutes. Jake's campaign remains the freshest the longest, with cheesy car chases and one liners that put a smile on my face, but his final chapter reuses a fair amount elements from Chris' campaign. That's to be expected though, as Chris and Jake are meant to meet here, but they still feel a little too similar at times. Ada's later chapters recycle a lot of the same scenes from the other three chapters with minor tweaks here and there, so you end up feeling as though you're going through the motions, tying loose ends rather than playing as a seperate character.   The Ugly: (the game's major failings)  The PC version's load times and compatibility issues with most computers and hardware make it unquestionably inferior to the console versions upon which the game was built off of. It can take anywhere from 8 minutes to 15 minutes just to reach the main menu even on a good computer, while far more graphically intense games zoom past it, which is completely inexcusable in this day and age. It absolutely cripples this port's lastability by comparison, and though infrequent, the occasional crash will make that 8 - 15 minute wait between startups feel all the more brutal. That the game has been out this long for PC and still has these issues is a shameful neglect of its players who are already wary of this game's reputation for being so unlike any other Resident Evil. There isn't even a chat box to use and communicate with the rare person who joins your game, so if you don't have a mic, you're left with only the character's generic 'thanks!' or 'look out!' commands. It's no wonder the PC multiplayer lobbies of this port are ghost towns when it takes so long to load and your ability to communicate is being harshly limited without such a basic feature. Imagine having no way to explain a monster's weakness while your partner continues to get hurt by it, not noticing what the monster is doing and soaking up resources for it. It would be very frustrating, naturally.   Final Verdict: (CONSOLE version) 7/10  Resident Evil 6 is a very functional, varied game full of cheese that'll give you many hours of brainless fun. If you go into it with the same mindset that you would when approaching a John Woo action movie, you'll have a blast. It's silly, but it seems to be fully aware of that, and just tries to do its own thing.  However, and I cannot stress this enough, play the console versions.  Were it not for the load time, the occasional crash wouldn't be such a big deal and would have remained merely in the Bad, but when combined it makes the experience of playing the PC version not worth the awesome collaboration with Valve's own Left 4 Dead 2 gang and the inclusion of the 250+ enemy minigame, No Mercy mode. Were it not for the lack of a chat box, newbies wouldn't be such an annoyance, but without the ability to explain a bosses weakness or where to go, they simply slow down your game rather than help you in any way that your AI partner couldn't do better than them. It all contributes to the game's lonely multiplayer scene, with more than a third of the game's content going purpetually unplayed (nobody plays Mercenaries, No Mercy, Agent Hunt, or even the other campaigns, just Leon's). It seems unlikely at this stage, but I hope dearly that Capcom fixes the unforgivable startup times, as well as the compatibility issues for many common brands of graphics card. Until then, I recommend Resident Evil 6 as a whole, but not this version of it. There is no excuse for missing basic PC gaming features and 8 - 15 minute load times in the modern era of gaming. Shameful display.

The good stuff:  --- The game offers not one but four campaigns! This is pretty cool considering the 4 couples you have which means 8 characters - each with a different personality, extra attack or weapon and importance when it comes to the storyline. Also, enemies approaching you differ in each campaign. The same goes to the locales. While Leon and Helena traverse through the big city, a cemetery and a cathedral offing dozens of zombies Chris and Piers do the same but in China. They are attacked by J'avos - these are infected people with the ability to plan their attacks and can also use firearms.  --- Graphics / cutscenes / sound effects -> production value. Well, after episode 5 it was obvious the creators would take this to another level. The game looks stunning and the atmosphere is there. The coop and action sequences once again decrease the horror elements but nobody can say they did not try! Also, there are dozens of cutscenes and in the game's menu you can rewatch all. Altogether I'm sure it will take at least 2 hours to go these in one sitting.  --- Longevity. Once again we have collectibles that come in the form of emblems. I have found many but could not find a lot either. There are no more treasures as collectibles. Instead, there is something else that is dropped by the enemies and they represents points. This amount can be used to purchase skills. These can then be levelled up. 3 skills can be active at a time and there are enemy-specific ones, too. So, you and your coop partner need to work together and decide who equips what. Multiplayer also returns in the form of Mercenaries and there is now a new game mode called Agent Hunt.  The bad stuff:  --- 4 campaigns: In terms of story and characters this is really good but there are too many intersections. In fact, there are boss battles you need to play twice. Really? Of all this it is Ada's (4th) campaign that is the worst. First of all, almost all the areas are familiar and you encounter hardly any new enemies. Throughout all the campaign you know what's going to happen and the ending is a total letdown. Not only this but Ada plays alone. Your friend assumes the role of a so-called Agent - a guy who's just there so that the creators can tell they did really make a coop game. Agent wears a mask and does not have a real name. In the cutscenes you see Ada alone and throughout the campaign Agent cannot interact with anything. You cannot open doors or chests, you cannot solve any puzzles and no QTEs for you (which is actually good). You can pick up bullets, of course and fight with Ada but feel like an unnecessary character who does not even have a story.  --- Cheesiness: If you thought episodes 5's dialogue was bad you are in for a great surprise. Some of the conversations the protagonists have are just dumb. In fact, you can easily guess what will happen next. The script should have been reworked at least 3 times to eliminate some of the worst dialogues this franchise has ever seen.  --- Boss battles: They are waaaaaaaay toooooooooo loooooooooooooong! You battle the same guy while he assumes at least 3 different forms one after the other. The tactic is different as well as the environment. It is not necessarily a problem but the game is very difficult and also you are 100% sure you eliminated your foe when he returns once more to annoy you. I have to admit the enemies are great (each one of them poses a real threat) but you battle them for too long. This gets boring and aggravating considering the difficulty of the game.  --- Difficulty level: This game is annoyingly difficult. From time to time you get a QTE which is next to impossible to complete for the first time. Missing it will result in a death cutscene - well, I appreciate the developers wanted to show me what cutscenes they had conjured up in their mind but this is still pretty annoying. Boss battles can be a pain and the controls do not help either. It is a sad thing to say since this game enables you to do pretty much everything: you can run, do fistfight, dodge and even slide. And finally: you can walk while aiming at an enemy! The problem is with the turning and the speed. Also, the camera does not help and sometimes you get attacked because our heroes are looking at what's going on elsewhere in the distance.

There are 4 campaigns in the game, each played with different pairs of characters. All the campigns are intertwined with each other, showing each pair's journey through the main storyline. There is a LOT of gameplay here if you want to experience it all. Each campaign seems to play differently as well. It's a pretty great setup. Leon's campaign reminded me of Resident Evil 2, while Jake's campaign reminded me of Resident Evil 5.   This game feels janky and unpolished a lot of the time. The dialogue is lacking and unimpressive. The graphics are mediocre, primarily from low texture quality and repetitive use of objects, textures and the like. Elements in many levels just feel all the same, with just the geometry changing. Some areas look visually impressive, but it's rare and short-lived. The controls and camera are ridiculous at times, but that's always how the Resident Evil franchise has been. Luckily, there are a lot of custom deaths when you fail quick time events, and they never get old.  The level of quality varies GREATLY throughout the game... the beginning of Leon's campaign is just awful, stereotypical, and poorly executed. It gets better later on, though. Jake's campaign felt more consistent and solid, while also being less over-the-top.  Despite all the bad, the game is actually fun COOPERATIVELY. I wouldn't recommend playing this game if you're by yourself, since relying on the AI is not fun, and you can share the ridiculousness of the game with a friend. It's like watching a bad movie and making fun of it... it ends up being fun. I highly prefer Resident Evil 5, as it's better in every single way, but if you're looking for another Resident Evil game, there's a lot of content here.

The problem is probably with the port, the game is clearly made to be played with a controller. Trying to run with a keyboard during a chase will drive you insane, especially with all the ridiculous fixed camera changes. Seriously, I'm still trying to finish Chris's campaign, that last chase is absurd! And without checkpoints!   Quick time events were the main cause of my deaths. Which is a shame, because when you're going around killing zombies or whatever it get's pretty fun. But before you know it, you're thrust into one those obligatory race, underwater(really?), chase sequences, quick button smashing that all games seem to have nowadays and then everything goes to hell.   The combat gameplay is good, it feels great to be able to take down a zombie with your hands. Every character feels different, the dodging mechanic works (once you get the hang of it) and the weapons, while not the best, definitely doesn't detract from the game.   The story is... fine. Your usual bag of cliches. Although it succeeds in creating a frenetic apocalyptic atmosphere.The characters are great for the most part (though I wish there was a bit more of race and gender diversity). It was nice seeing Leon and Sherry again. But can someone explain to me why the hell does Leon have feelings for Ada? They were together for like, 2 hours, in RE2! Ugh! All his scenes where they mentioned this were groan worthy.   The atmosphere is really where the game succeeds Especially in Chris and Jake's campaign, the set pieces looked great, from Europe to China, they all had a distinctive feel. Unfortunately, the first half of Leon's was really out of pace. They tried to bring the survival horror aspect back, but it doesn't work anymore, not with the frantic combat style of the game.  Overall I'm disappointed. This game could have been great, but it fails in its execution.

I won't spoil story here so..The short of it is :  Nice setting(RC), good game, nice campaign length, good music and voice acting, nice mechanics/controls.  RE:6 is a pretty damn good game despite the hate some people give it. If one has to say it isn't a resident evil game anymore; I would say that the series really hasn't been 'Resident Evil' since code veronica or the first 3. It kind of got the hitman absolution treatment. Also going back to the city is wonderful since RE has been on this rural muddy/washed out colored binge for a couple games. They finally made a dark game again.. The addition of other game modes and mercenaries is also pretty awesome.   It remains linear though like 4-revelations which is my small nitpick since I love to splore in games.  The only thing that bums me out is the (so-far) lack of weapon upgrade parts. The QTE's are actually pretty nice and short compared to other games where you can be asked to spam a key super fast for 30 sec.  I would easily give this an 7.5 to 8/10 if asked but to me I am fully satisfied and would really only want more re6. :P   More info:  I have been a fan of the RE series since playing/owning the first three at release on the ps1. I stepped away after code veronica and never cared to return since what I saw of four looked way too different from the RE games I knew and loved.   Only recently I have gotten into the later games 4,5, revelations and now six.  I would argue that they finally got rid of all the clunky mechanics that were only around because of the controllers and limits back then. While I love the old ones the best this one feels top notch gameplay wise out of the recent titles.  For instance the pause and shoot was from 1-veronica since you could not free aim and had to tap on the up down to shoot high or low. They kept it in 5 to be a throwback and somehow make it hard or something.   In Resident Evil 6 you can finally dodge and melee proper, though it will tire you and have a short cd. (non-spammy). The gun play feels good and the sound effects are really nice. Being able to roll out of the way or land on your back to shoot from the floor is a great touch. Graphically the game is beautiful and benefits greatly from Sweetfx.   In my opinion RE6 feels like what 4-revelations should have been controls wise. Those clung on to old mechanics to make you think they were staying true to the old play style. In 6 they shed all that, made the mechanics/controls more fluid/responsive and finally let it be a decent TPS instead of a slow clunky one.  This title takes you back to the city and the shambler type zombies come with that. You will find that sometimes it is better to run than it is to keep fighting. I wish we could have RE 1-veronica playstyle back but since that is gone, six is a good entry to the series.

So this is a rather straightforward sequel to RE5. Graphically its much improved, if with a more bleak color palette. Like 5, its music is less dynamic than 4's. The story itself is typical action/horror movie fanfare with four perspectives; Leon & Helena, Jake & Sherry, Chris & Piers, and Ada, which follow the respective tones: 'Horror' filled with references to the more traditional, almost survival horror games, Pursuit 'horror', being perpetually chased and harassed, Some ♥♥♥♥ed kind of mish-mash of emulating modern cover shooters and RE5, And actually feeling similar to traditional RE games. Overall a satisfying greasy fast food burger of a story, if you go in not expecting much, you'll be happy.   There is some redemption in the gameplay and consequently The Mercenaries mode. The gameplay is less horror and more action themed in general, with dodge moves, invincibility frames, quickened reloading, and a perk system to choose upgrades from. Melee combat has been refined and advanced, making things like a run through mercenaries without firing a bullet very possible. The character selection is also comparable to that of RE5, with an added cameo of the cast from L4D2. Yup. Your friends can call you Coach here, too.   Overall, not bad. Get it on the cheap.

Zombies, abominations, and rampant viruses. Many games have touched on those keywords, but CAPCOM's Resident Evil series has set the table for the zombie-killing survival horror genre. Since the first game, the series has strived to capture the struggle of surviving in zombie-infested mansions, cities, and laboratories with nothing but your wits and whatever weapon you manage to get your hands on. With an evil pharmaceutical company's creations running amok, it falls upon you to uncover their secrets and get out alive. Over time, the borders of the series have shifted and parted to suit the changing times, but as I've noted with Resident Evil 6, the newest addition to the series, the core has remained the same.  Resident Evil 6 is the creation of fusing the fourth and fifth game together while keeping aesthetics of the first three games scattered about in select scenarios like trudging through a dying, infested city or escaping from a seemingly invincible foe. Taking place a few years after the events of the previous game, the world is on the brink of another bioterrorism catastrophe, and it's up to a handful of distinguished individuals to put a stop to it, all the while bringing the masterminds to justice. Returning to the fight are four original fan favorites: Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield, Sherry Birkin, who is a grown woman at this time and Jake Muller's partner, and Ada Wong, who stars in her own campaign as she did in RE4's Separate Ways campaign. All characters are joined by new partners to assist them in their campaigns, of which are four divided into five chapters each.  A few words of warning: the main game's campaign is much longer than 4 and 5's story. Each chapter can take up to an average of an hour and a half of your time, and a campaign can take up about half of your day, even if you're the speedrunner type. It's a good thing that the campaigns are varied, else those hours spent would be unbearable.   Leon's campaign is a callback to the days of Resident Evil 2. Although Leon is joined by Helena Harper, a regretful woman armed two powerful weapons, there is no safety in this. The campaign guides the player through many dark and eerie locations that keep them tense and alert, and the zombies faced by Leon and Helena are soupped up to match the times and advanced controls. It can be easy to be caught off guard and overwhelmed by the varieties of zombies, but they can be quickly dispatched with a calm mind and a quick trigger finger. For those wanting survival horror, Leon's chapter delivers.  That said, the opening sequence can leave the player baffled at the abruptness of the situation. The President is a zombie, the surrounding city is infected, and a cathedral owned by the big bad villain is supposed to hold all the answers. On top of that, the guilty Helena Harper is tight-lipped and doesn't explain herself to Leon until the end of the second chapter. On multiple occasions the agent asks for exposition or reasons to which Helena waves her hand, choosing to jeopardize what little trust there is between each other for the sake of theatrical deliverance at the right moment.  And let's not forget to mention Simmons, the villain whom the players must fight four times before he finally dies. Granted, the boss fights take place in spectacular arenas and there's enough ammunition to force the next sequence, but the sheer tenacity of the villain weighing against the exasperation of both the players and the characters themselves leaves a bad taste. If Leon's campaign was a filling dinner, the ending with Simmons was a sour tart that took too long to finish.  Chris's campaign is more of what RE5 offered, that being survival action rather than survival horror. With the army of BSAA troops at Chris's back and Piers Nivans, a talented sniper, at his side, the campaign transitions into a third-person shooter play style where cover is much more important, especially against enemies who use firearms. There are no zombies for the Arklay Mansion survivor to fight. Instead there are the J'avo, which are humanoid enemies like the Ganado and Majini from the previous games. The difference with the J'avo is that they are able to mutate body parts in response to getting shot, which can result in a variety of enemy types that force the player to change tactics.  CAPCOM had tried to appeal to the Call of Duty fans with the Chris campaign, but in doing so they lost some appeal to the fans of the RE series. The campaign focuses too much on action and throws enemy after enemy at you without giving the ammunition or health needed to tackle them at times. Another gripe with the campaign is the final level and its overuse of the camera. Typically the camera would be over the shoulder of the player, but in the final sequence the camera is unreliable as it focuses on a large BOW that players have no hope of destroying at the moment. To make matters worse, the controls follow the camera just as well as they did when the cameras changed in the first few games. This makes running from a foe or looking where you're going an unsavory challenge.  Jake's campaign is hands-down the most varied of them all. Players are taken for a rollercoaster ride through urban warzones, avalanche-prone mountains, a deadly manor, burning streets and even an undersea research facility. The enemies are the J'avo and BOWs again, but while the player can dispatch them with ease, a new foe inspired by RE3's Nemesis chases the characters through all missions. Layered between the various fight and flight elements is the personality of the campaign's two characters, Jake and Sherry. They're personable enough for players to relate to and they're interesting and determined enough that one can't help but root for them. Not to mention the awkward yet adorable scenes between them... Other than a few unforgiving parts in the levels (snipers on an icy slope, for instance), Jake's campaign is exciting, rousing, and a hell of a lot of fun.  And as per usual, Ada's campaign sets out to provide exposition and tie up loose ends left dangling during the three main campaigns. Her gameplay has many stealth elements, staying true to her character playing games behind the scenes. As she encounters all of the main characters in their campaigns, she also fights the various enemies in each campaign: zombies, J'avo, and BOWs. Beaten only by Jake's campaign, Ada's run is filled with variety and backstory, although trying to decipher a story by CAPCOM is a Herculean effort in itself.  Yes, like most CAPCOM games the story is lacking. Here's a brief summary: It's a one-sided love story that results in a mad clone of Ada, the death of the President, and a Chinese Raccoon City. Given that the series loves to make its characters remark that every city with zombies reminds them of Raccoon, maybe CAPCOM just has a bad case of nostalgia that most fans have gotten over by now.  RE6's controls are a far cry from the tank mechanics of the first few games. The heroes can perform mad dashes, move while aiming, physically attack on whim, and dodge attacks by rolling, ducking, and sliding with minimal effort. Adding to the formula is a new mechanic that allows you to counter an enemy's attack with one of your own, provided you have the reflexes to execute the counter. Cover, which was used in some places in RE4 and 5, can be taken anywhere. By pressing the aim button near a wall or object, a character can snap to the cover and peek out to shoot at hostiles. It's a gimmicky mechanic that needs more refinement, but other than that, the new controls are easy to get a hold of.  If you're not griping about the story, then you must be having difficulty with the camera. In short, not bad, but not the best that CAPCOM has created. If you're going to try RE6 out, I'd recommend renting it before making the decision to buy it.

Score: 5/10  Be sure to stock up on canned food, weapons, medical supplies and gasoline as Resident Evil 6 satisfies the un-dead gamer horde but leaves more to be desired by the living.  It’s 15 Years after the Arklay Mansion incident and the biggest project in Capcom’s history, Resident Evil 6, looks to carry on the elements of what began as a horror series. But instead it just proves that bigger isn’t always better. Despite delivering a game with four campaigns and loads of online features,Resident Evil 6 lacks the means to either scare you or impress you.  At times it embraces its old school heritage, pitting its heroes against the un-dead horde, horrific creatures and rather farfetched –who-put-this-here-puzzles. The game is incredibly dark, tension is rife and yet it simultaneously tries to be the largest, most action packed entry in the history of the franchise. Every facet of Resident Evil 6 leans towards a western-style cinematic. Lengthy fire fights, driving sequences, falling sequences, crash sequences – I refer here to a particular incident involving a helicopter, bullet train and skyscraper – all of which result in something that is erratic and never sure of itself, delivering brilliance one moment and something far less spectacular the next. In short,Resident Evil 6 is begging to be a movie.  Capcom promised bigger and we got bigger, although it may have exaggerated to the degree in which the four individual campaigns differed. Each campaign is seven to eight hours long and on top of that there is the familiar Mercenaries and new Agent Hunt Mode. In Agent Hunt, players are able to drop-in and out of online games, as either a zombie or other C-virus abomination – similar to that of Left 4 Dead-, in an attempt to hinder the progress of other players and ultimately force them to give it up, turn it off and go to bed, which is great fun until somebody does it to you.  Rather than infuse characters and storylines along a singular campaign, the game separates them across four individual threads. This layered narrative, whilst new to the franchise, sometimes works against the game play. As the campaigns cross paths, the game forces players to replay sequences – some of which really ought to be played once- nothing is gained from this repetition, as plot revelations only come from cut scenes/ dialogue and not in-game action.  Quick-time events are prominent to the point of distraction. The new cover-system is disappointing and really isn’t necessary at all –the only time I ever found myself using it was during the inane and equally pointless tutorial- and the skills mechanic is mundane. Not only are you limited to the most basic of upgrades but the game only allows you to equip up to three at once and rightly so because you won’t want to spend your points on more than three anyway.  Resident Evil 6 offers vast improvements in terms of the cooperative game-play experience both on and offline. Resident Evil 5 was notorious for its empty-headed AI partner system but this time around, should you wish to play on your own, seek comfort in that the AI does a great job of knowing what to do and where to go, assisting you when necessary and not taking your resources. When playing with a friend, the game capitalises on some great ideas but struggles with the execution. Often you find yourself standing around with nothing to do, whilst your buddy works his way through a handful of enemies until they’re able to open a door or lower a ladder.  Visually,Resident Evil 6 focuses on shadows and much darker, murky environments as opposed to Resident Evil 5’s sun-soaked African locales. The result is a Resident Evil experience players will be familiar with but the overall aesthetics leave you wondering why Capcom didn’t realise it sooner. The Unreal Engine 3 does little justice to Capcom’s flagship title and to be honest, there are a lot better looking games out there. Not to take anything away from Resident Evil 6, it’s just too similar to its predecessor to take any real preference.  For most fans, the love of the franchise began with the first time you found a zombie crouched over Kenneth’s corpse in the Arklay mansion. Or the moment the Cerberus –zombie dogs- crashed through the windows. These are the signature moments that we remember. The love of the old Resident Evil came from these moments, these self-contained incidents of horror. But Resident Evil 6 does everything it can to abolish this trend. In a reversal of roles,Resident Evil 6 looks like it draws from its western blockbuster counterparts, Paul Anderson’s over-the-top action thrillers, rather than focusing on the fundamentals that made it great and led to the movies to begin with.  Under any other name, Resident Evil 6 could be great. Breathe fresh air into a stifling and dull genre. Sadly, it just isn’t Resident Evil.

I am generally not a fan of the Resident Evil series; both the gameplay and storylines usually leave me underwhelmed. But far be it from me not to give credit where credit is due; Resident Evil 6 gives you /a lot/ of content. Its first campaign is probably as long as the whole of Resident Evil 5's campaign, and you get three more campaigns in addition to that (in fairness, the next three storylines are shorter than the first, but it still an impressive amount). I also enjoyed the characterization of the various protagonists; you are introduced to each of them in a preceding campaign where they come off as one-dimensional, but when you actually follow their stories you realize there is some depth to them. The four campaigns intertwine in an interesting way, although each has its own unique set of levels that only briefly intersect at certain points. Lacking in any eye-catching set-pieces, the maps themselves are well-detailed (although the texture work could use some improvement), with good variety in design, albeit as off-the-wall unrealistic as I've come to expect most Capcom (and indeed, Japanese) games. Resident Evil 6 also boasts an impressive variety of weapons and monsters.  But while the above makes for an impressive list, the game fails in its actual gameplay. Its various campaigns offer some variety - the first is a pretty standard survival-horror in the vein of Dead Space or RE5, the second is more focuses on the shooting, the third campaign requires you to focus on your character's mobility more and the third has strong stealth elements - they all suffer from one common flaw: a huge over-reliance on quick-time events. You can't cross a room without encountering at least one QTE. They aren't even particularly good quick-time events; they are either incredibly easy (and thus pointless interruptions) or of the sort you can only master by dying first because the game doesn't give you any time to see what button needs be pressed before killing you. The developers also delighted in over-using the tired mechanic of having you run towards the camera while something deadly chases you from behind, complete with shifting camera angles (and controls) just to make things even less fun. None of these segments are difficult, and none of them are fun. The rest of the game is fairly standard shooting, albeit with monsters that tend to be a bit too resilient and with annoying multi-stage 'puzzle bosses' (complete with the dull-as-dishwater glowing-orange vulnerabilities mechanic that should have been put out to pasture in the Playstation era). And the less said about the ridiculous storyline and characters the better; computer games may never win awards for best writing but why is it that Capcom games always seem to pull from the bottom of the barrel?  All in all, I found the technical aspects impressive but while actually playing it I frequently found myself muttering 'I hate this game' when it forced an awful camera angle on me, or for its sluggish controls, or when it dumped me into another dull quick-time event, or even when it made me endure FOUR unskippable end-credit sequences. For all its modern amenities, overall Resident Evil felt mechanically archaic, like its developers were still stuck in the SNES era and hadn't noticed that gameplay had evolved significantly over the past 30 years. Barring the over-reliance on QTEs, I might have begrudgingly given this game a recommendation, at least for fans of the franchise; it's colorful and incoherent return to the series' strengths. But the over-reliance on quick-time-events so ruined the experience that I cannot do otherwise than to warn players away from the game.

This is a decent Resident Evil title. And no, RE is not a horror game anymore, just get used to horror themed action already. RE6 improves drastically on gameplay and mechanics, finally giving us typical TPS controls with dedicated attacking/shooting on a trigger rather than using the action/confirm button for that.  Health now is measured by a bar composed of 6 sub-bars (?) which will regenerate  only  if one is not completely depleted, and the complete depletion of one results in the character being knocked out. Herbs now are turned into pills which recover one sub-bar each. That health system makes harder for the player to die against huge hordes of enemies, but doesn't allow them to abuse of it as in other games, making a good system if you hone your skills properly.  The player now has a stamina bar which depletes whenever they make a physical attack. Opposed to the previous titles in which you could only attack physically an enemy with knives or something in similat fashion. This broadens the possibilities of damaging enemies in many aspects since physical attacks deal a considerable damage, but punishes players who overuse it, since guns are there, as always.  Each campaign is themed around a type of gameplay, with Leon and Helena on a more classic take, hacing zombies and other type of monsters as enemies, Chris and Piers with a more modern take with Ganado-like enemies (J'avos) that resemble more a third person shooting game and Sherrie and Jake's which focus on a smaller combat/shooter aspect with some stealth and exploration sections. There's also another campaign which combines aspects of each, but that will be available only after completing the game.  The new skill system is much simpler than the weapon customization, but doesn't feels quite as glamurous, specially since how the customization worked on RE4 (which only went backwards in my opinion, REvelations is the only one that has a custom system that feels nearly as satisfying).  In terms of story RE6 is horrible. Is like they had ideas for the story, decided to scrap them and, for some reason, decided to made it apparent on the final version. Although it can be enjoyed, the story of the game is just plain bad.  I recommend this game if you're a more open-minded fan of the series or someoen who enjoy shooters in general. Chris however, in combat tears it up, as he has a grenade launcher that destroys everything. Jake and Sherry are ok, but the game has a bad habit of coming out of a movie sequence with the infected beating the crap out of you while you are still frozen and unable to move. In some cases they get 3-5 seconds of free shots in, which on pro difficulty is enough to die. Ada was fun, though I wish all the characters could have carried the magnum, as it is still the most powerful weapon in RE games. Bottom line? This game would be worth full price with less QTE's, better camera angles, and smoother transition between the movie clips and the game. As it is, it's worth the sale price I paid for it, and I am happy I played through it, though I doubt I will replay it as I have RE4 and RE5 (3x each, and getting ready to replay RE4 in HD)

If you're playing on co-op, this is a lot like RE5, just with a quantity over quality approach. Recommend at a steep discount - never at full price. The campaigns (4 of em) are not worth it, though there is a lot of mostly mediocre content here, so it'll last you a while.   The campaigns are pretty bland and average for the most part; it's Resident Evil meets Michael Bay x1000. The storyline is peppered with setpieces of the eye-rolling variety, where the characters' circumstances tend to be ridiculous to the point that you can't be immersed for very long before yet another near-death scenario rolls around... and another, and another, and so on. You're also likely to drown in quicktime events during these scenarios.  That said, the Mercenaries extra content is pretty great, particularly the No Mercy mode, which includes far higher enemy spawns as well as Left 4 Dead characters & enemies. It quickly turns overwhelming given the number of enemies that swarm you and is easily the most redeeming facet of the game, from my experience at least.  The controls are mostly decent with a controller, the largest exception being the cover controls and the fact that hopping over objects is glued to the same button / key as sprinting. Prepare to unintentionally hop or slide over a lot of stuff the second you run nearby. That aside, the controls aren't too bad - definitely different from RE4 and RE5 though. And yet, the controls are horrible with a mouse & keyboard, which is disappointing considering that those were amazing in RE5. At any rate, you're afforded the ability to move while reloading and dive, dodge, and buttscoot around while shooting, so that's nice.  So to reiterate: Buy it on sale. Definitely do not buy it at full price. Quantity over quality here.

This game is garbage. You cannot remap controller bindings nor can you disable the controller from the options to use Xpadder. When I tried to remap the controller settings, I was unable to select anything to replace the controls I wanted to remap, nor could I exit out. The only way to exit out after selecting something to remap is to either A; close and restart the game or B; unplug the controller so it defaults back to the mouse and keyboard, kicking you out from the controller remap screen.  My specific problem happens to be with the camera controls. For some reason, everything else works just fine except for the camera. When I tilt the right joystick up, the camera turns right, down turns to the left, left tilts down and right tilts up. This means that Capcom is either under the impression that people hold their controllers sideways with the bumper pads facing the left, or they're just incompetent. It's almost as if they didn't playtest this game before publishing it.  I played a co-op campaign with a friend and we encountered the following problems:  #1: Enemies stagger when damaged and they do not take damage of any kind during their stagger animation, you have to wait for them to regain composure and point their gun at you before you can shoot at them again, which can last up to five seconds per stagger. Otherwise, you're wasting your ammunition on nothing. In fact, this applies to all enemy animations, from the giant bestial zombies 'hatching' to a zombie mutating its limbs after taking damage.  #2: Melee is shoddy & botches constantly. You will run up to an enemy you stunned with a flare grenade only for your arm to swing over the zombie as it's writhing around during its stun animation. Then you'll turn back and take another swing and botch again, only to get hailed by gun fire with your back to the zombie. Should you successfully connect, you can flip a zombie on its back and stomp its head in to kill it. The problem is the zombie flies two feet away from you, giving it a chance to get up before you can finish it off. Should you run up to it in time, the prompt to kill it only appears about 1/3rd of the time, letting him get up to melee or shoot you anyway.  #3: Bullets can phase through walls so taking cover means next to nothing.  #4: Enemies spawn from nowhere and always right behind you.  #5: Enemies with powerful artillary are cheaply place around corners & behind doors to jump-kill you instantly. We encountered a zombie with a sniper rifle hiding around a corner and were killed the instant we crossed its line of sight.  #6: The game is stingy with health drops. The game rarely gives you health item drops and the scripted health items are far and few between. I was revived from the brink of death by NPCs more often than I ever encountered health items. Once you do encounter herbs, the game awkwardly employs it in your inventory. First, you mix the green and red herbs, which create a pill packet. You'd think that'd be the end of it but no, you have to then assign it to your case and use the healing item by pressing the 1 key. This is all that the 1 key is ever used for.  #7: The inventory is stupidly limited. Let me stress that this is not a horror game, it is an action-horror game. It expects you to mow down hundreds of enemies & to do it with less than 300 bullets between every gun, which includes grenades and health items. I'm not being hyperbolical.  #8: Skillpoints. The skillpoints constantly gyp you out of getting valuable items like ammo or the even more coveted health items. Skillpoints are all you get 2/3rds of the time from either killing enemies or smashing crates. This wouldn't be such a bad thing if skillpoints weren't a worthless feature of the game. I unlocked level 3 for firearms, level 3 for defense and level 2 for fixing the swaying aim of the gun and I noticed no notable difference. Much like in Evil Within, where the gun is fixed to miss 2/3rds of the time, the aim is fixed to constantly sway and force you to miss, even if your actual aim is perfect.  #9: Aiming the gun is 50% of the challenge in this game. The crosshairs mean nothing, the red dot at the center which dances across the screen constantly is what matters. Lining up your shot is nearly impossible unless you're at point blank range or you have cover that makes it impossible to hit you.  #10: If you get shot and lose a full block of health, your character is knocked down and you have to sit through a five second animation of him shakily getting up and dusting himself off, making it possible to take damage multiple times and to be killed, punishing you for getting hit even once.  #11: The game uses the spacebar for absolutely everything, from opening doors, to sprinting, to climbing walls. This is a massive problem when you're trying to sprint away from a horde of enemies and end up climbing a structure instead because your character was just barely close enough for the context sensitivity to change, which ends in you being shot to death.  #12: There is no genuine challenge to this game, the game's challenge is defined by cheap encounters, limited inventory and a broken control scheme.   Just play Resident Evil 7 instead.
